instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-2915: What is 820-2915? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP5V_S0: What is PP5V_S0? PP5V_S0 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S0 working state..
definitions.PP3V3_S0: What is PP3V3_S0? The "PP3V3_S0" rail in a MacBook logic board is a power rail that supplies 3.3 volts to the system when it is fully awake (S0 state). .
definitions.PPVCORE_S0_CPU: What is PPVCORE_S0_CPU? This is the primary power rail for the CPU that powers the CPU, known as CPU vcore. Without this, the machine will be braindead. .
definitions.PP1V05_S0:
What is PP1V05_S0? The PP1V05_S0 power rail is for various components on the logic board that require a 1.05V supply voltage in the S0 (on) state. This voltage rail is likely to be used by the CPU (for VCCIO), PCH (Platform Controller Hub).

.
definitions.PP1V5_S0: What is PP1V5_S0? PP1V5_S0 is a 1.5v power rail present when the machine is in an S0 working state.
definitions.PP1V8_S0: What is PP1V8_S0? PP1V8_S0 is a power rail that is present when the machine is in an S0 state, meaning it is fully turned on, not sleeping or hiberating .
definitions.PP0V75_S0_DDRVTT: What is PP0V75_S0_DDRVTT? PP0V75_S0_DDRVTT is a 0.75v power rail present when the machine is in an S0 working state .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
Board would not come on at all, Replaced L7770 and now it turns on, but now it turns on, stays on for about 2-5 seconds, then shuts right off, 

any ideas?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
I am using a 85watt, and there is a battery plugged, but the battery may be bad, 

would the mac come on without the battery with the 85watt? 

I can only get it to start with the battery being plugged in, and currently do not have a second battery to test,

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message: voltage on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> only charger plugged in????

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
[QUOTE="nelo1012, post: 27782"]would the mac come on without the battery with the 85watt?[/QUOTE]

Yes, as long as it is a genuine charger.

How does the SMC area look like? Any corrosion around it?

You might be missing a S0 power line or have a power line thats out of specification
When probing this make sure the fan is spinning otherwise its not in a S0 state, so you might want to keep plugging the charger in and out to keep starting it back up.
So while the fan is spinning what are the voltages of:
- <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL>
- <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL>
- <SIGNAL>PP1V8_S0</SIGNAL>
- <SIGNAL>PP1V5_S0</SIGNAL>
- <SIGNAL>PP0V75_S0_DDRVTT</SIGNAL>
- <SIGNAL>PP1V2_S0</SIGNAL>
- <SIGNAL>PP1V05_S0</SIGNAL>
- <SIGNAL>PPVCORE_S0_CPU</SIGNAL>
- <SIGNAL>PPVCCSA_S0_REG</SIGNAL>

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
Firstly go get an ORIGINAL 85W charger, none of that Ebay/Amazon garbage as it will not work half the time only an original Apple one!
Measure PPBUS without a battery connected, should be 12.56V.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message: I am using original Apple 85W charger, I will get those measurements here shortly, thank you guys for the help
